Perhaps the best way to explain it is with an example.  See the 
attached Python script and Powerpoint file with results.  This script 
simulates 5 coupled reactors in a line, with the left-most reactor wall 
moving with a prescribed Gaussian velocity (relative to fixed lab 
coordinates), and the other 4 walls moving in response to pressure 
differences.  The response of the wall to pressure differences is 
intentionally set to a small value, for a more interesting solution.  
Setting K larger keeps all reactors at the same pressure. All walls are 
adiabatic.

Note that this script will not run with released versions of Cantera 
(<= 1.5.3); it works with version 1.5.4 available through CVS now, 
which will be released in zip, tar.gz, and Windows binary format 
'soon'.

Dave


--Apple-Mail-9-527087096

On Jun 1, 2004, at 7:05 PM, d_braithwaite wrote:

> Dear Dave,
>
> I'm=
 writing because I'm having trouble figuring out how to combine 2
> (or bet=
ter, multiple) kinetics reactors in pressure equilibrium
> which are subjec=
t to an imposed Vdot.
>
> I read your response to a similar question dated =
Feb04 (and your
> zerod.pdf), but I still don't quite understand.
>
> For e=
xample, if I have two reactors 1 and 2, and would like to have
> the P(1)=
=3DP(2), but Vdot(1 and 2)=3Dsome function, would the setup be
> as such?
>=

>            ||
> Reactor 1  ||  Reactor 2
>            ||
>   Wall wA-fle=
xible
>   Wall wB-Vdot-prescribed
>
>
> or, would it be more like
>
>
>    =
        |             |
> Reactor 1  |  Reactor 2  |  Reservoir 3
>        =
    |             |
>   Wall wA-flexible   wall wB-Vdot-prescribed
>
>
> Th=
anks for any tips you can give me.
> -Daniel Braithwaite
>
>
>
> <<<
> On F=
eb,2004 Dave Goodwin wrote:
>
> It is currently not possible to specify a f=
unction for the rate at
> which a wall moves from Matlab, but you can do it=
 from Python. If you
> want to run your simulation in Python, all you need =
to do is this:
>
> 1) Create 2 reactors that share a common wall (A), and m=
ake it
> flexible
> enough to maintain pressure equilibrium.
> 2) Add a sec=
ond wall (B) to reactor 2 with a specified vdot rate vs.
> time. This will =
actually change the total volume, not just volume 2,
> with time, since the=
 rate of volume change for each reactor is
> computed
> by summing over all=
 of its walls. Thus, the rate of change of volume
> of
> reactor 1 plus rea=
ctor 2 equals the specified vdot for wall B:
> dV/dt_1
> + dV/dt_2 =3D vdot=
(A) + (vdot(B) - vdot(A)) =3D vdot(B).
>
> The only reason this can't be do=
ne from Matlab too is that I haven't
> gotten around to adding the necessar=
y interfacing code to the Matlab
> toolbox. It's not hard to do, and I'll a=
dd it to the list of
> requested
> enhancements.
>
> Dave Goodwin
>
>
>
> O=
